G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: This action is brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and/or G.L. c. 209, § 37, and/or G.L. c. 215, § 6, as applicable, for modification of a prior custody and parenting-time order of this Court.

G.L. c. 209, \u00a7 37.proposition: This action is brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and/or G.L. c. 209, § 37, and/or G.L. c. 215, § 6, as applicable, for modification of a prior custody and parenting-time order of this Court.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This action is brought pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and/or G.L. c. 209, § 37, and/or G.L. c. 215, § 6, as applicable, for modification of a prior custody and parenting-time order of this Court.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7\u00a7 3, 6.proposition: Venue is proper in Norfolk Probate and Family Court because the prior order was entered here and the parties and the Children reside, or have resided, within the jurisdiction of this Court.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28 (1).proposition: Since the entry of the May 15, 2021 Judgment, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting the welfare and best interests of the Children. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; *Ryan v. Brigham*, 358 Mass. 200 (1970).

*Ryan v. Brigham*, 358 Mass. 200 (1970).proposition: Since the entry of the May 15, 2021 Judgment, there has been a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting the welfare and best interests of the Children. See G.L. c. 208, § 28; *Ryan v. Brigham*, 358 Mass. 200 (1970).
*Ryan v. Brigham*, 358 Mass. 200 (1970).support_reasoning: The proposition concerns the standard for modifying child-related orders under G.L. c. 208, § 28 based on a substantial and material change in circumstances affecting the children’s best interests—a domestic relations concept. Ryan v. Brigham (the text provided actually concerns a criminal sentencing review/writ of error matter) addresses double jeopardy and due process in the context of sentence review by the Appellate Division, not post‑judgment changes in circumstances or custody/visitation. It therefore does not supply authority for the claimed proposition and appears to be miscited or contextually inapposite.

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: The introduction of a household member with a history of assaultive behavior and a restraining order, combined with actual incidents of intimidation, physical contact with a Child resulting in a mark, and police involvement during the Children’s presence, constitute a substantial and material change in circumstances under Massachusetts law. See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns initial custody allocation and the need for explicit findings about the impact of domestic violence and the existence of a c. 209A order; it does not address what constitutes a “substantial and material change in circumstances” for purposes of modifying an existing order. The court requires written findings when there is a restraining order and domestic violence, but nowhere does it hold that the described combination of a violent household member, incidents involving the child, and police involvement amount to a substantial and material change in circumstances. Thus, it does not support the specific modification standard stated in the proposition.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “The Legislature reached a similar conclusion in respect to shared legal or physical custody. General Laws c. 208, § 31, provides that ‘[i]f, despite the prior or current issuance of a restraining order against one parent pursuant to chapter two hundred and nine A, the court orders shared legal or physical custody … the court shall provide written findings to support such shared custody order.’ A G. L. c. 209A order was outstanding in this case, and the judge made no explicit findings regarding the effect of shared custody on the child.”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: The introduction of a household member with a history of assaultive behavior and a restraining order, combined with actual incidents of intimidation, physical contact with a Child resulting in a mark, and police involvement during the Children’s presence, constitute a substantial and material change in circumstances under Massachusetts law. See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case focused on joint physical custody and the ‘best interests’ standard under G.L. c. 208, § 30. It does not address modification of custody based on a substantial and material change in circumstances, nor does it discuss the legal significance of a new household member with a history of assaultive behavior, restraining orders, or related intimidation/abuse incidents. The only relevant factual mention is an alleged misconduct by a step‑sibling, which is treated as one factor in the best‑interests balancing, not as a doctrinal statement that such conduct constitutes a substantial and material change. Accordingly, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that Chelmsford schools were preferable to those of Bristol, particularly for the child with special needs; that uprooting the children would be detrimental to their interests; that the move would cause a reduction of the father’s parenting time that would not be in the children’s interests; that misconduct allegations against a step-sibling weighed against increased time in the mother’s household; and that there was insufficient evidence of financial imperative to justify the mother’s move to Bristol.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: These new circumstances directly affect the Children’s safety and welfare and therefore warrant reconsideration and modification of the existing custody and parenting-time order. See *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The proposition is about new circumstances affecting a child’s safety and welfare as a basis to reconsider and modify custody and parenting time. Rosenthal v. Maney holds that modification of custody requires a material and substantial change in circumstances and that the relocation and a court‑imposed temporary change in custody, without more, did not constitute such a change warranting modification. The opinion does not discuss ‘new circumstances’ specifically in terms of direct impact on safety and welfare, nor does it find such circumstances warranting modification; instead it reverses a modification for lack of adequate changed circumstances, so it does not support the proposition as phrased.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A judgment modifying custody must be based on findings grounded in the evidence that, since the date of the prior custody order, there has been a change in circumstances ‘of sufficient magnitude to satisfy the governing principle by which the court must be guided in these cases, namely, whether the transfer of custody will be conducive to the welfare of the [child].’ Fuller v. Fuller, 2 Mass. App. Ct. 372, 376 (1974). ‘The uprooting of a child . . . should be done only for compelling reasons.’”}

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.proposition: These new circumstances directly affect the Children’s safety and welfare and therefore warrant reconsideration and modification of the existing custody and parenting-time order. See *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981).
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.support_reasoning: Schuler concerns modification of alimony and child support based on alleged financial changes in the payor spouse’s circumstances. It does not address custody, parenting time, or changes affecting children’s safety and welfare as a basis for modifying custody orders. The case is cited there only for the general proposition that a material change in circumstances is required for modification of support orders, not for custody/safety-related grounds, so it does not support the specific proposition stated.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination in Massachusetts is the best interests of the child. G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The paramount consideration in any custody or parenting-time determination in Massachusetts is the best interests of the child. G.L. c. 208, § 31; *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the “best interests of the child” standard in Massachusetts custody law, tracing its historical roots and reaffirming it as the controlling, paramount consideration in custody determinations. The court cites prior cases (including Yannas) and makes clear that custody under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) is to be decided based on the child’s best interests, confirming the proposition for which it is cited.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas… (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

*Felton v. Felton*, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).proposition: The Court has broad equitable powers under G.L. c. 215, § 6 to make such orders as are necessary to protect the health, safety, and well-being of minor children subject to its jurisdiction. See also *Felton v. Felton*, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).
*Felton v. Felton*, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the Probate Court’s authority to modify visitation and to limit a parent’s religious instruction only upon a demonstrated showing of harm to the child, but it does not ground that authority in, or even mention, G.L. c. 215, § 6. Nor does it broadly characterize the court’s equitable powers in general terms; instead it focuses on evidentiary requirements and constitutional considerations in visitation/religion disputes. Therefore, this case does not provide direct authority for the proposition about broad equitable powers under c. 215, § 6.
*Felton v. Felton*, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).relevant_excerpt: “In all events, the question that comes to the courts is whether, in particular circumstances, such exposures are disturbing a child to its substantial injury, physical or emotional, and will have a like harmful tendency for the future… The decisions hold such an infirmity to be fatal to an action seeking to limit materially or to cancel visitation rights.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that exposure of children to domestic violence, severe conflict, or abusive or threatening behavior in the home is contrary to their best interests and may warrant restrictions on parenting time or the imposition of safeguards. See *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996); *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion in Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas concerns standards for custody, joint vs. physical custody, and removal of children from the Commonwealth under the “real advantage” test. It does not discuss domestic violence, severe conflict, or abusive/threatening behavior in the home, nor does it state that exposure to such circumstances is contrary to children’s best interests or warrants parenting-time restrictions or safeguards. Using Yannas for that specific domestic-violence-related proposition misattributes its holding and reasoning.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices. Unless one is to apply a fixed but arbitrary rule, the issue can be resolved only on a case by case basis. The effect on the child of any removal is most important. An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31A.proposition: G.L. c. 208, § 31A and G.L. c. 209A reflect the strong public policy of the Commonwealth to protect children from abuse and domestic violence and to consider evidence of such conduct when fashioning custody and visitation orders.

G.L. c. 209A.proposition: G.L. c. 208, § 31A and G.L. c. 209A reflect the strong public policy of the Commonwealth to protect children from abuse and domestic violence and to consider evidence of such conduct when fashioning custody and visitation orders.

*Rosenberg v. Rosenberg*, 33 Mass. App..proposition: In light of the above, maintaining the current parenting-time arrangement without modification would not adequately protect the Children’s best interests, and would fail to give due weight to the changed circumstances and the heightened risk to their safety and emotional welfare. See *Rosenberg v. Rosenberg*, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 903 (1992); *Hersey v. Hersey*, 271 Mass. 545 (1930).
*Rosenberg v. Rosenberg*, 33 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The proposition concerns modification of parenting-time arrangements, changed circumstances, and risks to children’s safety and emotional welfare. Rosenberg v. Rosenberg is an alimony and property-division case that does not address child custody, parenting time, best interests of children, or modification standards. It therefore provides no authority for the proposition cited and is being used out of context for that point.
*Rosenberg v. Rosenberg*, 33 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: When the entire marital estate is as large as it is in this case (the joint assets of the parties came to $21,970,830), need, even as related to station in life, recedes as a consideration; equitable distribution of the marital assets becomes the main task. Such an approach is consistent with the view that the dissolution of a long-term marriage … somewhat resembles the dissolution of a partnership, and that careful thought must be given to the various contributions of the partners to the marital enterprise.

*Hersey v. Hersey*, 271 Mass. 545 (1930).proposition: In light of the above, maintaining the current parenting-time arrangement without modification would not adequately protect the Children’s best interests, and would fail to give due weight to the changed circumstances and the heightened risk to their safety and emotional welfare. See *Rosenberg v. Rosenberg*, 33 Mass. App. Ct. 903 (1992); *Hersey v. Hersey*, 271 Mass. 545 (1930).
*Hersey v. Hersey*, 271 Mass. 545 (1930).support_reasoning: The case concerns modification of a custody order, but its holding is that the lower court erred by changing custody from the mother to the father; the Supreme Judicial Court reversed the modification and left the existing custodial arrangement in place. The opinion emphasizes that the child’s welfare is the paramount consideration and finds no evidence that remaining with the mother is contrary to the child’s best interests. It does not stand for the proposition that maintaining the current parenting-time arrangement would inadequately protect the child or fail to account for changed circumstances; rather, it rejects modification in the absence of evidence of harm or detriment.
*Hersey v. Hersey*, 271 Mass. 545 (1930).relevant_excerpt: “This is not a proceeding to discipline the respondent for her shortcomings. It is not a proceeding to reward the petitioner for any wrong which he may have suffered. It is a proceeding solely with reference to the custody of a little girl. The governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child. … The conclusion seems to us irresistible that it was plainly wrong…to change completely an order of custody made by the court four years before….”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: Reasonable and narrowly tailored modifications, such as prohibiting the Cohabiting Partner’s presence during the Defendant’s parenting time with the Children, or requiring supervised parenting time for the Defendant while the Cohabiting Partner remains in the home, will better serve the Children’s best interests while preserving their relationship with the Defendant in a safe and appropriate manner. See *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012); *Felton v. Felton*, 383 Mass. 232 (1981).
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: Hunter v. Rose does not address or approve specific, narrowly tailored visitation restrictions like prohibiting a cohabiting partner’s presence or requiring supervision while a partner remains in the home. The decision applies a general best-interests analysis to a custody allocation and parenting schedule (including substantial visitation and webcams) and focuses on parental alienation, stability, and relocation, not on crafting targeted restrictions involving a third party’s presence. Thus it does not provide authority for the particular modification remedies described in the proposition.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “The judge’s custody order gave Rose frequent contact with Jill, including parenting time one weekend per month in Massachusetts, five weeks in the summer, school vacations, holidays, Web camera sessions three evenings per week, and telephone calls once per week.… Moreover, the judge stated that, should Rose decide to move back to Massachusetts, the parties must work in good faith to adjust their parenting plan to meet Jill’s best interests.”
